editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE ENGLISH ROGUE A NEVV Comedy. As it was acted before ſeveral Perſons of Honour with great Applauſe.
LONDON, Printed for William Thackeray at the Golden Sugar-loaf and William Whitwood at the Golden Lyon in Duck-Lane, 1668.

list.head: The Actors Names.
list.item: Gonzetto A great Lord of Venice.
Cornelio A Citizen of Venice & a Coffee-man

list.head: Women.
list.item: Ermenia A young Lady contracted to Euſames and beloved of Gonzetto.

div.head: To my worthily honoured friend and Patroneſs. MRS. ALICE BARRET.
div.p: SO many already have aſſum'd it as a priviledge, that it is now become a current cuſtome to prefix a Dedication to ſome one, whoſe Judgement and ingenuity may both grace the ambitious Authour, and protect his weakneſs, otherwiſe you had eſcap'd the trouble of being Guardian to this Brat, whoſe Parent was unable to maintain it. To be plain; I have caſt it at your Door, neither better nor worſe to expect its fate: yet with ſome confidence of a favourable reception, ſince your Generoſity and Nobleneſs were ever wont to correſpond with Charity: whereof my ſelf am ſufficiently ſenſible. I beg your pardon for this offence, but cannot promiſe to do ſo no more. However I ſubmit to your worthy ſelf, whoſe intimate goodneſs and ſerenity have hitherto ſo far obleiged me, that I muſt ever (as moſt due) ſubſcribe myſelf (as really I am)

closer.signed: Your moſt humbly devoted ſervant to command. Tho. Thompſon.

sp.l: AT a New Play all Poets muſt tell news.
Ye'r welcome to the labour of a Muſe;
Who do's implore (and 'tis your pitty worth
Your helping hands to bring her firſtling forth,
And let me tell ye, 'tis moſt neceſſary
Since 'tis her firſt you act more kind and wary,
Shou'd you be rough and harſh in what you do,
The brat might prove defective long of you.
S'lid then all's ſpoil'd, your expectation croſt
The Muſe diſcourag'd and her labour loſt.
Come, come, for once be kind and rul'd by me
And let your ſmiles crown its Nativity.
We question not Lucina's help, if you
Vouchſafe her ſafe delivery 'twill do,
And that with Pomp and State, whilſt ye are by
Your preſence makes it a ſolemnity.
The beautys preſent blazing ſtarr's appear
As good Omens to this our hemiſphear.
Nor can we, whilſt ſuch luſtre they diſpence,
Doubt of a favourable influence.
But I digreſs, the gravid Muſe I left
Of all ſuccour except bare hopes bereft.
She's in the Midwives hands and much endures
And cannot be reliev'd; except by yours.

div.head: A NEW COMEDY Called the Engliſh Rogue.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: I See I'm Fortunes Favorite to the End
In a ſtrange place to meet my deareſt Friend!
sp.p: But prithee tell me Ben. how has thy pollitick pate maintain'd thy Nobleneſs? I am ſure you needs muſt thrive, Since by your laſt Letter to me at Madrid I was informed you have baniſh'd the Conceit of Marriage.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p:
O yes, I thank my Fate that fancy flew quickly, and
ever ſince in your Art I have been no ſmall practitioner.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: But how did your Miſtreſs Selina reliſh it? That Admirable Doxie!

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Doxie indeed! whoſe laſciuious life, had it been concealed till I had married her, had ruined me for ever!

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: What Man, the chaſte, the virtuous Selina!

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: No the unchaſte, vicious Selina! whom (after my Annual ſervices of Adoration to her Shrine, and unfeign'd vows of being hers conſtant for ever) I found to be as foul within, as I eſteemed her fair without.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Why this is fine • faith. By Jove Ben: Ile tell thee theſe women are juſt like weather Cocks, that turn too and fro at every puffe of wind: So they are as fickle in ſetling their Love on any one man, as a Phanatick Parſon's unwilling to alter his Religion when he is forced to Conform or looſe his Benefice.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: I have found it ſo.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: 'Tis a remarkable obſervation, that any man that has eyes and ears muſt of neceſſity credit it: but there are ſome ſuch Buffs in this land, that won't believe what their ears have heard, or eyes have ſeen: but take their Wives as we do Conies to pen up, whilſt every Dame to requite the kindneſs, will find a conveniency to tempt the next young Gallant that paſſes into her Chamber, and there diſcharge the burthen of her deſire without the leaſt conſideration of making her Husband a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: That's moſt certain.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Moſt certain and you ſo certainly beſotted as reſolve to marry; I thought the little practice you had made in my Art might have been a ſufficient Embleme to demonſtrate all women's levity.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p:
Prithe no more of't: I am as far from having a good thought of womens conſtancy, as ever I was, and once you
know I was your only ſchollar, had your cunning ad ungues, (and if without boaſting) can ſay I ſtill retain it.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Then let us plot and practice: this is a City affords good faces, wee'l inſtantly go view it, you one way, I another: but be ſure before you ſtrike ſearch out the nature of the creature.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Never ſear it, Ile warrant thee boy I hit right.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: That done you cannot miſs entrance into any Venetian Dame, for my part I doubt not my rogury will never faile getting me a Miſtres, though it were in the Land of Chaſtity.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: I confide ſomething too in mine.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: Come then lets to our Inne, there wee'l ſever:
As thou haſt begun, good Fortune, help us ever!
WHat ſudden alteration do I find,
That does ſo pleaſe and yet torment my minde!
sp.p: I know no reaſon for it: there was nothing in the Maſque laſt night but what was pure and ſplendid.
sp.l: — Ladies as fair
And beautiful as is the morning ſtar!
Now I have pri d into ſecret Art,
That Ladies glittering Eyes can wound a heart!
I muſt to fair Ermenia a captive be,
I'm her Adorer, ſhe my Deity!
But here ſhe comes: ſhe'es Beauties Paragon!

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: You have your anſwer Sir and may be gone. To Florentio.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Since Madam. I'm diſmis'd ſo ſcornfully,
To move a change I muſt preſumptious be,
Think on the good Euſames mis'ries, he
Who like a careful penitentiary,
Bedewes his bed with tears, as they are due
To diſcontent, and all for love of you!

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Why Sir for me? he knows it is in vain
To hope Ermenias love to reobtain.
Firſt let him change his coat of poverty,
To wealth and honour: and then think of me.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Let not your height contemne his humble ſtate
But Saint like pitty the unfortunate!
He once was high too, but in each degree
Where he did love, he lov'd with conſtancy!
Since firſt he lov'd you, to that love he's true,
Yet ſuffers Martyr-like for love of you.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: I beleive once he lov'd me well indeed,
And mine did equal his (if not exceed) aſide and ſighing.
But I conſidred not the miſeries
Of marriage then, which now I do deſpiſe,
A maiden life all others does excel:
Pray tell Euſames this, and ſo farewel. offers to go out.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Pray Ladyſtay: one requeſt does remain.
He ask no more,

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Then that you ſhall obtain.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: She turns again, I doubt be will it'h end
Make a deep intereſt in her for his friend! aſide.
But be it how it will, Ile overhear:
I am too lofty to be touch'd by fear.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Are you reſolv'd alwaies to live amaid?

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: I mention'd not how long but thus I ſaid
A Maidens life excels all other lives:

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: But Maids contracted are as good as wives! (ſpoken whiſperingly)

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: O me! ſhe ſounds!

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: That ſtory in the ear
Has made her pride fall, and my ſpirit fear.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: She breathes agen,

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Madam how are you now?

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Well, but better had I made no vow
To poor Euſames: Florentio wee'l withdraw.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Ile follow Madam, your will is my law.
Ye powers of love and friendſhip crown the end
Of this deſign with comfort for my friend!
Great God of love, what mighty power unknown
Haſt thou now us'd to mee, more then thy own?
It was thy conduct ſure and thy deſign,
And not thy power alone that vanquiſht mine:
As a great Captain in the wars to his Name
Of every conqueſt gain'd, joynes all the Fame,
Though 'twas not only by his power got
But by the Armies by his Conduct brought:
So when thy power could not do't alone
Thou then diſt lead her troops of virtues on?
And now too ſoon I feel by my ſurprize
Thou haſt not only darts but peircing eyes!
Then as thou art great and powerful bee Juſt!
I am enforc'd to love, and love I muſt.
sp.p: The news Captain, any Letters from the Army yet to his Highneſs?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Yes Sir laſt night.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Are the contents divulg'd?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Yes ſome two daies ſince half our army was beſmear'd with blood, the other half took flight, and the fam'd Carionil with ſome number of cheif Commanders were ſurrounded with a multitude of Enemies, and almoſt hopeleſs of ever ſeeing Venice agen: yet when they heard our noble General cry, fight, fight for Venice till you dye, they with ſuch vigour redoubled their blows, adding wounds to wounds, blood to blood, dead to the dead, till by the favour of that potent God, with whom it is to give the victory, they through the Multitude quickly run their way, and after for that night ſounded a retreat
sp.l: And in the interim receiving a ſupply
Early next morn refac'd the enemy,
sp.p: Whoſe Army in number doubled ours, but at the firſt onſet with manly courage
sp.l: — We diſpers'd them quite,
Part we took priſoners, part we put to flight.
sp.p: The reſt lay gaſping on the ground fruſtrate of future hope or remedy,
sp.l: — Few eſcaped alive.
Of laſts nights newes this is a Narrative.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: I joy wee were ſo ſuccesful in the end, though to our loſs at firſt.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I could have gladly wiſh'd my ſelf there, but that I was commanded to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: I credit you Captain, you have done your Country good ſervice.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: My Lord I muſt retire.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Farewell good Captain.
sp.l: I know not what to think much leſs to do!
I am in the flames and now I muſt go through?
Why ſhould I dote on one that is ſo mean?
But ſhee that's lovely to love is a Queen!
Ermenia thee I love, thy love I crave
Which if my wealth and fame can gain I'le have!
I fear no rivals, i've a double fate,
Too wealthy for contempt, too high for hate!

div.head: Scen third.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Florentio what iv'e ſaid ile do, provided he
Without contempt a conſtant Lover be.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Madam!
Be you as kind as he will constant prove
And make his joys as perfect as his love.
I dare proteſt by 'very Deity,
Hee'l ne'r be guilty of inconſtancy!

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Then whi le I live ile love him: tell him this
Though many court me, yet my heart is his.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: So I have prevail'd and for joy could fly
To tell Euſames of my victory!
O may the god of love, as he's begun,
Unite theſe too contracted hearts in one!
See here he comes: ile ſtand aſide
— To know how his thoughts fixed are
Whether to hope or fear or to deſpair,
Or whether he will into a paſsion fall,
For i've a double joy to baniſh all.

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.l: How joyfully the birds with warbling notes
Salute the morning through their gentle throats!
But day no ſooner does appear to mee,
But I complain a freſh of miſery
In love! imperious love!
Aſſiſt a wretched youth thou caus'd all this
And 'tis thy power alone can work my bliſs!
I cannot, dare not hope my friend can bee
So prevalent to regain her love to mee.
She is grown high, and yet muſt higher grow,
While I, for love of her, muſt fall too low! offers to go out

div.stage: (Euſames turns back and falls into a trance.)

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Stay, ſtay Euſames!
What ſtruck dum with fear
Of the ſad newes you do expect to hear
From me?

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.l: 〈…〉 fear
It is too 〈…〉 for me to hear!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: For love I mov'd, but ſhe her love deni'd,
And having ſo reſolv'd, ſhe thus reply'd:
A Maiden-life all other lives excel,
Pray tell Euſames this, and ſo farewel:

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.l: Then love farewel for ever!
And though from all my joyes I am betray'd
By thy reſolve to live and dye a maid,
I will not wiſh that thou mayſt live and dye
Such an unpittied, martyr'd one as I! offers to go out.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Be not ſo haſty: there remains behind
Aſentence from her, you'l eſteem more kind
Then was the other Cruel!
— While I live ile love him: tell him this
Though many court me, yet my heart is his.

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.l: O tantalize me not with hopes ſo vain!
Can ſhe ſo hate, ſo quickly love again
As if ſhe had her former ſcorn forgot?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: If you can think me falſe, believe me not.

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.l: Then I muſt credit it, O how the joy
Of thy ſucceſſe my miſeries deſtroy:
My heart's enliven'd with a freſh relief,
And double Comforts doe ariſe from grief!
So Palms preſt down, do ever riſe the more,
And ſpices bruis'd ſmell ſweeter then before.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: There's nothing now remains but your adreſs
To compleat hers and your own happineſs,
For if a Maidens vow was ever true
No doubt ſhe loves as fervently as you.
You need no 〈◊〉 ſince you know the way
Haſte too her then, tis dangerous to delay.

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.l: I will, yet ere I go muſt recommend
A parcel of poor thanks to you my friend.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Spend no more time in complementing me,
My recompence is thy felicity.
Couldſt thou enjoy Ermenia for thy Bride
I for my worthleſs pains was ſatisfied
But you looſe time.

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.l: He that a loyal friendſhip does regard
Heaven with hapineſs will him reward.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: ANd how and how? prethee begin, how are all things at Court?

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: O right to a hair, as I could wiſh or deſire, the Ladies very pleaſant and free, the Gallants very complacent and ſimple, out of which I have pickt out one to play upon, he is in quality and ability one of the cheif, and as I take it a very fine fool for our purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: His Name?

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Don Gonzetto, and for mirth to make up your Roguery, there is one Pego his man is reported for the prittieſt dreaming Puppy that Venice can boaſt off.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p:
Why then I perceive the Maſter and man are like to
be finely handled if they come into our •… tches, but how haſt contri'd it?

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: O this great Don is very deſperately in love with a young Citty Dame, and I perceive by his clipt tongue he wants a good Orator.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: With a young Citty Dame?

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: So I was inform'd.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Good luck ſend it be the ſame I heard off, for now ile tell thee Ben. part of my progreſs, I was no ſooner got into the body of the Citty, but I was crep into a croud of acquaintance: Ladies by whole ſale, and Cittizens by Bakers dozens, amongſt which I think I have pickt out two of the moſt pretious Ningles that the whole Citty affords: Fellows as rich as they are ſimple, and that I am ſure is beyond expreſsion; the one is S. Don Aquinto a high and mighty Mountebank who ſwears he has done many wonderful and remarkable cures, but if I don't catch his coxcomb into a trap, that all his medicines ſhall never draw him out, let him report me no man of my trade. His whole diſcourſe be it where it will, ſo there be any body to hear him, is of his cramp ſtage talk, of his great Cures of the Uvula, the Choliac a paſsio, the Polippus, with the reſt as Morbus Gallicus &c. which is enough to tire a crew of patient Saints were they his companions, but that he has this good faculty, when the reckoning is call'd, his purſe ſhall be ſure to pay fort; the ſecond is one Seignior Cornelio a very comical Coffee-man, and ſuch another Ignoramus, but that his tougue does not ſo much betray his ſimpleneſs. But here's the point, theſe two Coxcombs, are very paſſionately taken with two young Ladies, daughters to one Avaritius a rich reported Uſerer, and in ſhort by my diſcourſe finding their own weakneſs and my efficacy in Arte Amandi very nobly retained me for their Agent.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: There indeed you have got the ſtart of me, but ile follow cloſe.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Hark Ben. Let it be your care to bring Conzetto to our end of the Town among my crew that we may tye them all of a not, and then wee I ſo ſwing them! this evening we ſhall be at Cornelioe I Coffee-houſe.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Then there ile be ſure to meet you with my Don.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Do ſo for as I remember I was alſo informed Avaritius had a lovely Neece too, courted by many high Perſons of which perhaps he may be one, and then our plot lyes in a lump and muſt needs goe currant.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: But have you yet ſeen any of theſe Ladies?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Yes, and they are as pretty Creatures as ever I ſee, fair and each has a promiſing countenance of a very free diſpoſition, the Mother of the two Siſters was an Engliſh-woman. I have a plot for them both.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: But when will you put it in practiſe?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Forthwith, lets go viſit them inſtantly: our 〈◊〉 are ſuitable to the Mode, our Perſons proper, and for our tongues they need no tipping; but one thing always obſerv'd Ben. let not our Roguery extend to any criminal fact, that may merit the halter or the like, but tend only to a ſelf intereſt: then
sp.l: None will endeavour to condemn his Fate,
That playes the Rogue, and injures not the State.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: SIR, I like you well, and be aſſur'd that all my powers ſhall be imployed to do you ſervice.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.l: Ye'are truly gen'rous.
And 'tis my happineſs I 〈◊〉 could hope for
After ſo many ſtorms of adverſe fortune
To reliſh ſafety in ſo ſtill an harbour
And meet the favour of ſo good a Patron
Juſt in the nick of my diſpair. But Sir,
My future diligence and induſtrie
In whatſo're you uſe me, ſhall declare
How I can love and ſerve ſo good a Maſter.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Nobly ſpoken: accept me as your faithful friend.
My houſe is yours pray Sir be bold and welcome.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.l: I ſhall now take the confidence to think
That all paſt troubles of my youth, were of purpoſe by fortune meant, to make me reliſh now
Theſe ſweets more tartly.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Very likely;
And I muſt further add, that all her former kindneſſes,
Did leſs oblidge than this fingle one
Of making me the object of your friendſhip.
sp.p: But come Sir, will it pleaſe you take a diſh of Coffee to digeſt the news of the Diurnal.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.l: With all my heart! Sir I attend you: pray Sir —

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: 'Twere better be abſur'd than, trouble ſome.

div.head: Scen ſecond.
div.stage: Plot-thrift, Cornelio, Aquinto at the Coffee-houſe.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: 〈…〉 your word.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Here's your Enemy Don Aquinto the Mountebank.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Mum! take no notice till you meet occaſion.

sp.speaker: Cor,
sp.p: Enough,

sp.speaker: Aquin.
sp.p: Here a diſh of Chaclates.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Of your beſt ſpaniſh.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: You ſhall ſir.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Well, and how goes 〈◊〉 packquets, do the remedies go roundly off, ha'you good takings, ha?

sp.speaker: Aquin.
sp.p: Troth well▪
I find the people free and much inclin'd to do themſelves and me good.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: This is he that ſtrives to dam my trade by making ſtrange ſpeeches againſt Coffee — but I ſhall have ſomthing to ſay to his balderdaſh complication of hard words preſently — are you for Coffee ſir?

sp.speaker: Aquin.
sp.p: No ſir, the Berry is much degenerated from its proper vertue here in Venice by an abſur'd commixture which renders it very unwholeſome.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Sir mine's as good as any's in Venice.

sp.speaker: Aquin.
sp.p: That may very eaſily be when there's none good at all.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Tis the property of fools to condemn what they underſtand not.

sp.speaker: Aquin.
sp.p: Of fools Sir?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Yes Sir of fools. He that's diſgruntled at that Sir is a fool, — I think 〈…〉 .

sp.speaker: Aquin.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 Sir. Aquin draws.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Now it works ifaith.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Nay good Aquinto —

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p:
I, I, do kill me, you have no remedy againſt an hemp halter I hope: there I
•… pt him agen.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Nay pray ſir be p •… ed — ſee here comes ſtrangers

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Sir I ha' ſold Coffee this twenty years and have liv'd a man of reputation.

sp.speaker: Aquin.
sp.p: What man of 〈◊〉 would ben • with ſuch a Raſcal, that has liv'd upon parch'd beans, and boild water theſe twenty year by his own confeſſion.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Come pray Gentlemen let us moderate the buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: A man of honour, a pittiful Mountebanck, a dull decoying Fortune-teller, an impudent cloſe-bugete'd impoſter, one that gets his living meerly by choaking the multitude with hard words, and a little dirty dogs-turd compounded with a ſtrange conjuring charm, Hyperbolloticon-bombon or the like? a man of honour? ha, ha, ha. That excellent ifaith.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Yee ſhall but here, pray give me leave, this is he that cures all diſeaſes, and performes all Chyrurgical operations. He dextrouſly coucheth the cataract or ſuffuſion, helps all rheumes, ſpecks, Oungula or the nail in the eyes, dimneſs, pearls, weakneſs. He has the beſt remedies i'th world for all pains, ſickneſs Megrum Vertigo or the diſſineſs of the head he cuts and cures cancers, wens, ſore-breaſts noli me tangere, as alſo Morbus gallicus, or the French POX, (in great letters) running o'th reins, and in a word all diſeaſes and diſtempers incident to the body of man woman or child be it boy or girl,

sp.speaker: Aquin.
sp.p: 〈…〉 in ſome, but in you they are 〈…〉
〈…〉 , ha, ha, ha.
〈…〉 you and I have 〈…〉 a progreſs in your love with fair 〈…〉 a plot to make ye happy.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: With 〈…〉 ſhall we finiſh and come to the purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p:
We are not farre off — 〈…〉
[they whiſper.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Well 〈…〉 muſt needs be time.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 ſtay.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: 〈…〉 to pay, take money.

sp.speaker: Aquin.
sp.p: 〈…〉 I ſhall be even with 〈◊〉 incivilities.
Farewell ſir

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: A man of honour, farewell Dr. Diſtaff belonging to the wheel of Fortune.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Ile be with you 〈…〉 prefixt without fail.

sp.speaker: Aquin.
sp.p: Your ſervant ſir.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Welcome Gent •…
So 〈…〉 no way you ſay but by this 〈…〉 and her fathers conſent?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: No, for put caſe ſhe loves, as I dare warrant ſhe does yet there muſt be ſomthing cloſly acted, that may make it ſure, and not when we have brought our building to the height to be ruin'd with a puff.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Well I am reſolv'd to ſpend all my eſtate in contrivances but I will have my mind.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: And I mine — aſide.
But come lets to the Tavern, and there wee'l plot to accompliſh all.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Shall wee, a match then come on,

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: WHat ſtories are theſe I hear, Lucibella, ha what are they Lucibella? ſpeak Clara, concerning two Youngſters. that were tampering to ſpeak with you under the notion of buſineſs? what ſay you?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Only two young Gentlemen that deſire your leave to try our wits by ſpending an hour in diſcourſe with us now and then.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: S'lid ile h'none of that, if ye have a mind to husbands ye ſhall love and like where I pleaſe or ile know why not.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: That will be pritty i'faith, ſo we ſhall couple with two old Citizens, that are already grown out of faſhion for want of the rudiments of Gentility in their youth, together with two much brooding over their books and bags in their counting houſe.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: Come come I have a couple of Husbands for ye, grave and rich; and have ordered them to come to day upon a likeing, in the mean time trick yourſelves up handſomly and prepare to entertain them with diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: S'lid lets baulk the old man, ſtand cloſe

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: Well I muſt ſtreight to the Exchange, where poſſibly I may meet them and conduct 'em hither.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Save ye Ladies! we are ſomewhat bold to interupt your privacies.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: But we hope to find an eaſie pardon.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: That's eaſily granted Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: No doubt on't.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: I durſt have thought as much ere I came in.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: A very pritty humour; their both handſome men, pray heav'n I miſconſter not their errand.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Madam ſo ſtrange a curioſitie has urg'd me to this boldneſs, I found it vain to reſiſt: And to be plain we came with a reſolution to love and ſerve you; ſmile on me? Madam, I'me yours body and ſoul.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Very blunt and pathetical!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Troth I ſee I muſt be fain to put my ſelf forward, Sir methinks you might be doing.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Doing Madam?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Yes doing ſomthing.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Faith any thing with you Madam.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Ha ha ha, now he comes on two faſt:

sp.speaker: Plot:
sp.p: Now am I ſo mad with love, that by my virginity, I ſhall never be ſober till you quit me of that oath.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Then you may chance to dye raving.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Say you ſo? If I do, I am reſolv'd my Ghoſt ſhall walk and haunt you till it fright you into the ſame condition.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: How ſhall I know that?

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Now I think on't my affection's in expreſsable.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Well excus'd however.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Come what ſay ye, ſhall we make a mad match on't

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: As how I pray?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Why, make a reſolution to love one another, reciprocally in ſpight of Fate and the malice of the Devil.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Suppoſe I make this blind covenant, and you or I after we have feaſted our appetites with thoſe delights, may chance to clog our ſtomacks, and then turn to neglect, and fail in your appointed Articles, what ſhall be the forfeit for every ſuch default?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Why faith on your ſide to be tongue ty'd, and lye alone.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Good, and on yours — Cuckoldome, or ſo.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Agreed i'faith.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: In faith agreed.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: One denyal more, and by the love I bear you, which is as ſafe and ſound as any roach, ile turn Aſtronomer and hate all women in general.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Well, hang't for once ile make a blind bargain on't and buy a pig in a poke?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: And how goes ſquares Ben.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Faith, very roundly! we have made a ſhort cut on't.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: So, ſo, then we'l be merry, laugh and lye down, dance and ſing in ſpight of the old mans oppoſition, but firſ • lets ſing, what ſay ye Ladies?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I, I, come come, we'l help to make a Chorus.

lg.l: What need we uſe many beſeeches
Or trouble our brain with long ſpeeches.
If we love 'tis enough
Hang Poetical ſtuff
As the rule of Honeſty teaches
Chor. If we love 'tis enough
Hang Poetical ſtuff
As the rule of honeſty teaches.
Why ſhould we ſtand whining like fools
Or woe by platonical rules
If they love we'l repay't
If not let 'em ſay't
What need they the help of the Schools.
Cho. If they love &c.
But this muſt be won by Romances
And that by verſe and fine dances
A third do's delight
In a ſong yet at night.
You muſt crack a ſtring which ſhe fancies.
Cho. A third do's delight, &c.
This muſt be extoll'd to the sky;
That you can get, do but flatter and lye.
But that Ladi's for me
That loves fine and free
As real and ready as I.
Cho. But that Ladi's for me
That loves fine and free
As real and ready as I.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I proteſt a very pleaſant one.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Of your own compoſure I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: An abſtract drawn from our humour and diſpoſition, Madam.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: 'Tis well ayr'd too.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: You jeer Madam.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: You miſtake Sir.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Madam Lucibella your Father's coming down ſtreet with two Gentlemen homeward.

sp.speaker: Plot,
sp.p: Upon my life Aquinto the Mountebank and Cornelio the Coffee-man, what ſhall's do Ben.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Let 'm come weel not bauk them weel wheedle them into an opinion that wee were acting in their behalf aforehand that they might be entertained with more familiarity and greater courteſy.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: And for the old Man, Ladies with your leaves wee'l undertake to allay his pettiſh humour.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well Gentlemen uſe your own diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: And you yours with your new Suitors.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Sir, they enter.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: Come Daughters — how? — here's a new trick i'faith — Pray Gentlemen what acquaintance have you here.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: O Sir,

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: O me no O's ſir, ye owe me nothing ſir.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: But pray ſir.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: Pray me no prays ſir, pray to God if — ye'are ſo minded ſir, Pray ſir quoth A—

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: S'lid ſir ye are a man of the perverſeſt humour, that ever I met ſince I ſuck'd milk; what are you ſir, that you'l neither be ſpoken too nor give an Anſwer.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p:
One wou'd ha'thought your age and long experience
ſhou'd have taught you more civility to ſtrangers, then thus to tyrannize, though in your own houſe.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: You ſay well ſir.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: However they come to know it, they've nick't his humor right, Th' old mans chollar falls.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Now ſir ye'are ſomething more a man —

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: What then? ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Why pray ſir.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: Pray ſir agen?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: — Have but a little patience and i'l tell you the whole ſtory. —

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: Story? that were fine i'faith, do I ſtand here to hear ſtories? Sir tell me the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Why ſo ye ſhall if you'l but lend an ear —

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: No Sir ile lend neither of my ears.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Then keep 'em till the Pillory claims it own.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nick, Nick.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Excellent!

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: I ſee hee's uncapable of any civil ſociety, ile e'ne rant him, Ben. obſerve my ſtile.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Enough, proceed.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Venerable Sir, I ſhall take my leave — hark ye ſir, I ſhall have ſomthing to ſay t'ye in ſome other place, for extortion and bribery the two dam'd ſins 'oth age.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: You may remember ſir the defference between you and young Mr. Laviſh concerning a morgage, where you had like to have ſcrewed him to part with one half of his Eſtate to ſecure the other.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: And then to ſtop his mouth compounded with him for half in half.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: Gentlemen —

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Nay this is not all.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Remember ſir how ye abuſed his Higneſs bounty, which was to be diſtributed amongſt ſix Juſtice of Peace for their good ſervice ith ſickneſs time, when you with your two comrades, got it into your own hands, you caſt out the other three Juſtices and proved your own carvers.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: How —

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Nay ſir there's a Petition like to be exhibited by Juſtice Gizard and the other two injured parties, 'twas a high indignity, and his Highneſs muſt know it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: 'Tis fit he ſhould by this light.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: Well Gentlemen, I muſt withdraw, I beg your pardons — O my ſad heart, what to do, what to do!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Is he gone?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Ile warrant you for ever returning till wee are gone.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: VVee netled his Juſtice-ſhip i'faith.
VVhat news now.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Heres Don Aquinto and Cornelio are very deſirous to ſee you Ladies.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Prithee entertain 'em a while ith Hall and ſhew them the fine pictures. Ladies theſe are the men whoſe ſpokesmen we are to repreſent, and firſt Don Aquinto the mountebank, is one who ſpends all his eſtate beſides his little brains in inventing hard words for ſublime Courtſhip and imploying others to take preſidents out of the greateſt wits in Chriſtendome for that purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: The other in his expreſſion ſo low and blunt, that an hour with him is an abſolute divertiſment.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Hark is not that their tread? — noiſe of feet.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Doubtleſs, let us retire Ladies for fear of maring your paſtime.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Pray do if you pleaſe, behind the Arras away, away,

sp.speaker: Aquin.
sp.p: I have heard of Cherubins and Seraphins, but never ſaw I Angels cloathed in fleſh before.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: A high ſublime conceit.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Pox 'twas a complement an Age ago made to two Perſons of Honour by a ſtudient of Cajus Col. an intimate friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Mrs. Clara, let me not live to fill one diſh of Coffee more, but dye like a fool ſuddenly without making my will if I don't love ye — moſt heartily.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Thank ye, thank ye.

sp.speaker: Aquin.
sp.p: All the Coeleſtial beauties of the heavens, compounded in one only object, cou'd not more afflict and preſs theſe weaker opticks which (as thoſe leſſer lights call'd ſtars, do vaniſh and diſappear at Phaebus riſing glory) are as it were obſcur'd by your too glorious aſpect.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Methinks you ſhould have done well to have brought a preſervative againſt weakneſs of eyes along with you knowing what a powerful object they were to encounter.

sp.speaker: Aquin.
sp.p: True Madam, but men that are employ'd about affairs beyond the moon, cannot ſtoop to conſider matters ſubluminary; thoſe men whoſe larger ſouls ſtill aim at things immortal, know not how to condiſcend to converſe with inferial mortality.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I Madam, you may ſay what you pleaſe, but I proteſt my heart is as full of love, as a Church bucketfull of water.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Good, or as an empty oyſterſhel's full of brains.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: What you pleaſe Madam.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You much oblidge me Sir
And I cou'd wiſh ye had ſpent your Ceraphick courtſhip.
On a more worthy and deſerving object.

sp.speaker: Aquin.
sp.l: Pardon me Madam,
I muſt not bear you ſet ſo low an eſtimate
On your high merit: I muſt be bold
To rectify your judgement, and inform you
Of a miſtake; that none but your fair ſelf
Durſt have committed without apparent 〈◊〉 ,
Namely that you ſhould ſeem to intimate
Your matchleſs ſelf, excell'd by any ſhe
How beauteous ſoever. I could 〈◊〉 over
The various features of all forraign beauties
Engliſh, Italian, French and Dutch
Such vaſt experience has much travel taught me
With the Faſhions, Cuſtomes, Laws, con •… ions
Allow'd and ratified to each of theſe:
And yet all theſe and many more fam'd places
Are deſtitute of half that excellency
And divinity you ſtill bear about you.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: What a plaguy company of lyes the Rogue has wound upon one bottom.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Your language Sir has ſpoken you wordly, and withall I am ſo well certified of your generoſity and nobleneſs, that I muſt needs bluſh and own the conqueſt you already gained over my affection and weakneſs. I heard your noble Friend ſpeak in your 〈…〉 as greedily as griping Miſers liſten to the wills of of their deceaſed frinds wherein they are poſſeſt of large reve •… .

sp.speaker: Aquin.
sp.p: He's my deareſt and moſt faithful friend whom I am proud to intruſt with the diſpoſeing of my moſt nice affairs.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sir, he ſhall be ever •… ceptable as from you.

sp.speaker: Aquin.
sp.p: Immortal thanks, divineſt Lady!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Well Seignior Cornelia; heres my hand, and as I love pi •… y — thou art a pritty fellow, wou'd I were a young wench for thy ſake.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: O Madam, I take you at your wiſh i'faith. Ile en'e to the old Juſtice immediately: ſlid i'm ſo orejoy'd, — I know not how •… y breeches hang, farewell ſweet Madam: I muſt ſtraight to Plot-thrift and tell him this good news, farewell ſweet Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sweet ſervant yours.

sp.speaker: Aquin.
sp.p: Madam ſome extraordinary affaires exact my preſence at Exchange, I humbly take my leave and ſhall never be forgetfull to employ my friend in my own abſence to commemorate my beſt ſervices to your honoured ſelf, your ſervant ſweet Ladies.

sp.speaker: Both
sp.p: Yours Sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: VVee'l 〈◊〉 you out.

sp.speaker: Aquin.
sp.p: By no means Ladies, you ſhall excuſe me.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How now Gentlemen, could you hear all this while and not be realous.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Faith Coz. how didſt like it, did wee not play our parts worthy your applauſe.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: O incomparably.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Faith I ſear'd all had been ſpoyl'd, yea jeer'd them ſo home.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay thei'r leſs beholding to Nature for allowing e'm ſo many ounces of beard, ſcearſly to one dram of apprehenſion.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Come what ſhall wee do.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I what indeed.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Faith and troth lets take a walk together, and ſo with a littla freſh air digeſt our late pleaſant banquet.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: VVith all our hearts, and then wee'l conſider more leaſurely about accompliſhing our deſired ends.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Faith well adviz'd, come lets away we ſhall ore-reach their graveties.
sp.l: — As wiſely ſaid Lucullus
Old men are fools, when young men ſeek to gull us.

div.head: Scen firſt.
div.stage: Enter Euſames about to throw himſelf upon the point of his ſword and Florentio putting it off with his foot:

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.l: Perſue me not Florentio! let me dye,
Since ſhe is guilty of inconſtancy

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Can you ſo much your Chriſtian thoughts forſake
To murder life for a falſe womans ſake?

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.l: Could you endure ſo much miſery
Still to be dying and yet never dye?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Can you ſo ſoon to miſery bid farewel,
To meet with endleſs miſeries in hell?
Suppreſs this paſsion or it will undoe
Thoſe noble arts which you have ſtudied too,
Confound (what hitherto you've gaind) a Fame:
Destroy your parts and murder your good Name.

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.l: What friendly councel's given with what eaſe
By thoſe who never felt the like diſeaſe!

But I 〈◊〉
•… ower to perform what you give:
〈…〉 afford me means to live!
〈…〉 delay longer diſpence
No 〈…〉 my patience,
〈…〉 thoughts forthwith fulfil,
〈…〉 purſue my ſuite and 〈◊〉 my will. offers to kill himſelf.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Once more conſider: that you run a courſe
'gainſt honour and virtue! nay whats worſe
Offend thoſe ſacred. Deities, who preſerve
Our lives that we their pious Laws obſerve.
Tis not your dying thus that can recover
Your loſt content, for though a deſperate lover.
Self murder makes you dye in flames for ever,
From whence ther's no recovery! no never!

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.l: 〈…〉 and will forgive!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: When you deſtroy that life which they did give •
〈…〉 glorious a crime to commit
Out of preſumption of a 〈◊〉 for it.

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.l: Theſe morals all are 〈◊〉 away in mee
Who 〈…〉 and miſery!
I am paſt reaſon therefore 〈◊〉 in • ain
〈…〉 things again.
Since fair Ermenia does ſo inconſtant prove,

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 〈…〉 forbear!
That 〈…〉 before my Eyes!

Or do you think Florentio
〈…〉
One happy hour 〈…〉
〈…〉 , which ceaſe to do
Or elſe by your dying Ile dye too!

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.l: I live Florentio that thou mayeſt not dye.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Friends ſelf murder's Friendſhips cruelty.

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.l: But how ſhall I Ermenia's love obtain,
To hope for favour now is but in vain?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Nothing impoſsible with the powers above.

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.l: O that they would but petty one in love!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Come fear it not: all things will work forth'beſt
Mean time to ſleep, your paſsion wants ſome reſt.

div.head: Scen ſecond.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: NOw what think you on't Ben?

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Faith but indifferent.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: I have a double fear: I feel a kind of an itch of honeſty within me, down right honeſty to Lucibella.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: And I to Clara as I am a Chriſtian.

sp.speaker: Plot,
sp.p: But I fear 'will never agree with us long.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: As much fear I.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: And then the ſmall comfortable lives the poor wretches will have.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Nay I muſt confeſs they will be well hop'd up with two ſtaid husbands.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Yes like town bulls riding upon all they can leap. But hangh't handſome Engliſh Girls and good fortunes may tye us cloſe to their tails in tyme.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p:
O fie baniſh the conceit of Marriage! (in a jeering way.) what looſe all the pleaſures of a ſingle life, to be conſtraned to the humour of one fooliſh Woman? no viſiting of the Taverns without a peal from home; no courting of a handſome
Lady without a ſcore of ſcratches and the like; theſe were your own words ſir.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Well they were ſo, I deny it not, nor am I yet reſolv'd to do't: yet I am prompted much, Money and Beauty are two taking bates and muſt prevail.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Well conclude and ile joyn with you, either put forward or draw off: I dare ſwear they are honeſt.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Of that lets make a ſound tryal.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: To what an honeſt part my labors tend,
No roguery but has ſome honest end▪
sp.p: Lets to them.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: See here they are,

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: So, ſo, now Ben. follow my free fawning way directly and obſerve my motions.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Enough.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: O my dear Luci.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: O my dear Clara.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: O dear Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Well met.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Whither march you Ladies?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: To viſit ſir.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Who Lady? Man, Woman, Boy or Girl or what?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You are very inquiſitive.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: 'Tis the nature of the Country Madam.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis not your Nature I hope.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Perhaps while I am here, no longer.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Pray heaven it be not. (aſide)
Why to tell you true, we are going to neither man, woman, boy nor girl, but yet may meet many.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Wee are going to the Phyſick Garden at the City gate end.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Pleaſe you Ladies wee'l wait upon you thither.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: What ſay you Madam?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Pardon us fir, not for want of Love or reſpect but fear of our Fathers meeting us, or ſome of his Acquaintance, wee deſire to be excus'd.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Beſides it may be a means to obſtruct our future appointment.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: You councel well Lady.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: I muſt confeſs that love is ill grounded that deſtroyes it ſelf through ignorance, yet Ladies ere we part lets beg the happineſs of your company to take a glaſs of wine, here is a private Tavern at hand, beſides your Maſques blinds all diſcovery whatſoever.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Though Sir to grant your requeſt is a thing as unuſual with us, as thoſe that never did, yet to aſſure you of the good eſteem I have of you and your company, for my part I conſent.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Then I muſt yeild too.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: You honour us.

div.stage: Enter preſently agen in a Tavern with a drawer.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Pleaſe to name your wine Ladies.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: VVhat you like beſt Sir.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Canary I eſteem.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis granted.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Canary: you ſhall Sir,

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p:
Now Lady we are bleſt above the proudeſt of our former wiſhes, this happineſs was like a thing deſired but far from expectation, as men forlorn and wretched being content to dye and ſure to ſuffer, wiſh to live, although they fully
〈…〉

sp.speaker: Luc. and Cla.
sp.p: VVe 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And hope 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Heres the w •… and now 〈…〉 fill out drawer.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p:
Here 〈◊〉 ile 〈…〉
〈…〉

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: VVell 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: 〈…〉 diſhes full 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Thank 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: VVhat thinſt you of an Aire or two. (to Cozen

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: 'Twood not do much amiſs.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Ho Drawer.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Your will Sir.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Are the old Muſicians in the houſe?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Imployed?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Send them in.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: I ſhall ſir.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Now Ladies are you for a melancholly Love ſtory, or a merry Tavern catch?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: O fye, Love in a Tavern is as ridiculous as wine in an Alehouſe.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Then come muſitians lets hear the Tavern catch I gave you when I was here laſt.

sp.speaker: Mu.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

lg.head: The Song.
lg.l: COme let us bee frolick and call for our tipple,
Our pockets we'l empty & our veins we will fill
For Sack we'l not lack, nor will we be griple
But carouſe in deſpite of the two Topped Hill
Chorus. Parnaſſus ſhall paſs us
Nor will we enquire
For the front of the Muſſes
Tis Sack we deſire.
Let the Frenchman delight in his white wine & red
His vinide paree is but pitiful geer
Tis the brave Spaniſh liquor that brings us to bed,
It charms all our ſenſes and frees us from fear.
Cho. Wee'l baniſh the Rheniſh,
White Metheglin and brown,
Tis Sack we do love, ſo let it go down.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: How like you this?

sp.speaker: Luc. and Cla.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Theres for your pains. gives money.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Theres ſomthing more. more money.

sp.speaker: Mu.
sp.p: Thank you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Farewel, Exeunt Muſitians. my heart miſgives me. ſoftly to Cozen.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: I am ſomthing ſtartled too. ſoftly agen to Plot.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Hang't now we are in we muſt through.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Come, come Gentlemen, underfavour this whiſpering I fear portends no good.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: No hurt Ile aſſure you.

div.stage: They draw the Ladies ſeverally into two back roomes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Whether tend you Sir.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Only into the inner room Madam for more air.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Your meaning.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Very harmleſs.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p:
Now while they are whiſpering may I civilly ſteal a
glaſs of wine of two: I have enough I confeſs: but the Proverb ſaies enough will have more, and I will not croſs it, yet this Canary is ſuch a parlous liquor twill turn you a mans head ſo long round that at laſt it will ſet it where his heels ſhould be (drinks) as for example. reeles.
sp.l: But ſtand up Zachary the Bell does ring,
I dare not ſtay delay does danger bring.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: For ſhame ſir ceaſe to proſecute a ſuit ſo beneath your worth, and prejudicial to my reputation: I muſt not hear you.

sp.speaker: Plo.
sp.p: What a miſery is this to be forbiden to complain.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Fie as you are a Gentleman urge it no more.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Reflect upon my miſery and imitate the Gods in mercy.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Rather the Fiends ſhould it be ſo.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I can now think you no better then a counterfeit Atheiſt that would deſire thus to allure me from my purity.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: The Gods ſee every thing: Nature nor Art can any thing conceal from them.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Should I be guilty of ſo foul a fault, I ſhould impoveriſh my ſelf to nothing banckarupting my good Name and reputation, which who wants is a companion for ſuch wild people as never heard the Name of virtue, riches are fortunes trifles, neither to be deſpiſed nor doted on, but well us'd.
sp.l: Poor virtue is moſt rich, and vertue it ſelf
Was by the Antients held the greateſt wealth.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: In your diſcourſe you are too much a Stoick.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Young Ladies ſhould not be ſo utterly void of all compaſsion.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I muſt leave you.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Not without hope of comfort, let me but taſte of that which Crowns you famous, your Virginity.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I treſpaſs on my Modeſty to hear you, come ſiſter. offers to go out.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Stay Ladies.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You have chang'd your countenance, your looks now promiſe you civil.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: You are ſomthing altered too. to Coz.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Ladies thus low we bend, and rather wiſh our knees grafted to the ground, then riſe without a double pardon: not only to forgive but to forget.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Yet thus much wee'l ſay on our own behalfs, we had no end or aim to do as we deſired, but find away to ſearch out your affections.

sp.speaker: Luc. and Cla.
sp.p: Can this be true?

sp.speaker: Plot. and Coz.
sp.p: As Oracle.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Then riſe.
sp.l: Here then does all our former love rejoyn.
Pray heaven yours may be as pure as mine.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: If ere I move the like attempt-agen
Impute me not the baſe, but worſt of men.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I love you now as well as ere I did
Pray heaven you love me ſo, heav'n forbid.
sp.p: But that I ſhould.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Since now we have vow'd a conſtant faith on all ſides, I think it requiſite to work a means to compleat our happineſs.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: That we muſt leave to you.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: But we'l plainly tell you, leaſt hereafter you repent, we have no worldly fortune but what our outſides promiſe: yet within you'l find honeſt hearts.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: That's ſufficient.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: My Father has Gold enough.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: I and has the wit to keep it cloſe enough.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Phew, have you no trick for that?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Troth I have a brain ſeldome empty of invention, Ile ſet my wheeles a working and make tryal of one exploit.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Siſter we ſhall be late home.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I go, Gentlemen farewel good fortune ſpeed your ſtudy.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: We ſhall attend you on the morrow.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: We ſhall expect you.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Now we are new men.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: New married men that ſhall be ſhortly, well may we thrive no worſe in that ſtate then we have in the Batchelors and are happy ſtill.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: But we waſte time.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: True we have deep cheſts to dive into, it requires a great deal of cunning to contrive it honeſtly, or at leaſt without the Bar plea Fellony.
sp.l: — This once done
The fools are theated, and our loves are wonne.

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.p: COnvey this Letter Coz. unto my Lord Gonzetto, you know his lodgings, deliver it into his own hands.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Uncle I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Euſ
sp.l: What grudge in thee procures the new grown hate
Of thy Ermenia? what unhappy fate
Has fix'd her heart againſt thee, O that ſhe
Should violate her vowes of Conſtancy,
To make me miſerable: I ſee 'twere fit
That Lovers vows upon the ſands were writ.
sp.p: What are theſe? I muſt be gone.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Your company Gentlemen does obleige me much.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: Alas excuſe us Sir, it is not ſuch
Is worth your thanks, much leſs your obligation
Think it but worthy of your acceptation
And you will highly honour us ſince we know
For your favours many thanks we one.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Come lets not further complements commence
Your love to me extends all recompence.
sp.p: I have a ſuit to you.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: Name it and 'tis granted if it be
w'thin compaſs of my capacity.
sp.p: Or my Friends.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Moſt willingly.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I doubt it not Sir.
I have a friend deeply engaged (indeed contracted) to the Lady Armenia, you know her queſtionleſs.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: The Lord Gonzett's Deity.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: The ſame my queſtion is whether you think her inclinable to Gonzetto or any other?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Troth I think indifferent to any, but a little bending to Gonzetto by reaſon of the weight of riches he throws on her.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Very probable.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: But he's fire all over for her.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: 'Tis hotly reported ſo ſir.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Pardon me ſir that I dive into your thoughts, the Gentleman you ſpeak of is as I preſume your friend by name Euſames. I am bold in explaining, but aſſure your ſelf and him ſir, ile be his friend and Agent and can do much with Ermenia, and will.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: In ſo doing you will obleidge two friends at once, the one ſick of Love and diſpair: the other of ſorrow for his friends misfortunes. I was once his poor Agent too, and then ſhe promiſed faithfully to embrace him with all former love and reſpect: but ſhe had no ſooner ſet her eye upon this gliſtring Lord but ſhe forgets her vowes as if they were of no conſequence.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: I know all circumſtances, I will be very ſerviceable and I hope ſuccesful, I ſhall looſe opportunities, therefore for the preſent farewell.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: To morrow ſir ile waite on you, till then adieu.

div.head: Scen ſecond.
div.stage: Enter Euſames as in a field.

sp.l: HOw am I over preſs't'ween hope and fear!
'Tis paſt the time and yet he is not here.
sp.p: Would he would come.
sp.l: — Delayes in miſery and love.
Would breed impatience in Olymphick Jove.
sp.p: O here he is: I joy you are come Sir.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Yes I am, draw

div.stage: They fight Gonzetto ſtamps and enters a Guard.

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.p: I am ready.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Secure him in Fetters till further order.

sp.speaker: Guar.
sp.p: We ſhall my Lord.

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.p: Ha! is it ſo baſe Gonzetto.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: You are bold Sir.

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.p: You are impudent Bandogs, how am I conquered with oppreſſion! If you are men of civility permit a Gentleman a minutes conſideration, your reward ſhall not be wanting and the limits I'm now confin'd in, is a ſufficient ſecurity for me your priſoner.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: We will obleidge you ſo far Sir.

sp.speaker: Fuſ.
sp.p: Do ſo and ile be grateful.
Unfortunate Euſames.
sp.l: Who haſt endur'd the raging of the ſea
To enjoy two bleſsings Love and Liberty
And art no ſooner well arriv'd on ſhore
But both are loſt as much as was before.
Arm me ye Gods, with patience and content.
Manly to undergoe Impriſonment.
Guard!
Now ile walk with you: my guard is ſtrong
This is too ſharp ſure to continue long.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: I have heard much of him.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: He is our Country-man, and of rare endowments, genteel Parentage, and heir to a good fortune, had it not been conſumed by his Parents, for which poor wretch he ſuffers.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: She's very cruel to ſlight him, and ſettle her affections elſewhere conſidering the contract.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: I ſhall plead Scripture and prick her conſcience I fear ere ſhe and I part.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Do ſo, ile work the way croſs on my Lords ſide farewell.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Adeiu Coz.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Well met again Sir.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: I was juſt a going to the Lady.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: 'Tis too little purpoſe I fear.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: The reaſon.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Why Euſames out of a mad vein this Even. challeng'd Gonzetto who met him with a Guard and clapt him up.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: Yet not a pin the worſe: for you ſhall ſee.
To morrow Morn he's at liberty.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: It will be welcome news.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: Well fear it not.
If I'm deceiv'd Ile never truſt a plot.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.p: 'TIs ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: 'Tis true Madam.
We meet it in the vulgar mouth: beſides
I had it from the Captain of the guard
Who by command ſirpriſed Euſames priſoner.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Leave me. exit Priſ.
So ſtrange a boldneſs is familiar
With men of noble Births, that though they fall
So low, that others think 'em worthleſs; yet
They of themſelves ſtill hold the ſame eſteem.
And (what this Age thinks moſt rediculous)
Behave themſelves as high, though not ſo wealthy.
Such is Euſames fate: whoſe love at firſt,
I entertain'd, becauſe 'twas as rich as great:
But now being fall'n from his high eſtate,
Still thinks himſelf as worthy of my love
As er'e: yet ſomthing I fain would do —

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Well met Madam.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: I am come to chide you Madam, pardon me.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.p: To chide me ſir?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: I you Madam, you once lov'd a Gentleman named Euſames.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.p: O heavens! is my breach of ſacred Covenants made common.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Nay and was contracted to him.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.p: Too true indeed!

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Too true! nay ne're repent: although his fortunes low, had you but given him content he might have rais'd himſelf, indeed I needs muſt blame you.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.p: Proceed no further good ſir, I am touch'd to the quick, and heaven knowes I am ſomthing troubled.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Somthing, it muſt be altogether ere I leave you Madam, recall that love you have ſetled on Gonzetto, and render it to Euſames as his due: he poor man languiſhes in priſon for love of you by baſe Gonzetto's means, ſpend no time in recanting but uſe your utmoſt endeavour to gain his liberty.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.p: I can hear no more.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: S'lid but you ſhall! unnatural woman could you think the Gods had no bleſſing in ſtore for his great virtue? whoſe merit could purchaſe heaven it ſelf.
(Reverently ſpoke) aſide

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.p: Pray leave and hear me.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: O are you touch'd,

Hear me? what can you ſay; alaſs invention's barren in your cauſe, a double fee cou'd not procure one word to ſtand in your defence. Did you not vow, proteſt and ſwear your ſelf a real votareſs to his deſires. Did he not with a true and faithful heart when he was in his height of happineſs honour & ſerve you. And do you think it now reaſon ſufficient to ſlight and diſaffect him becauſe fortune at preſant frowns upon him!
ha! do you think there's deſert in nought but money? O unworthy? your corrupt ſoul belyes your form and beauty, and ere I go ile cleanſe it, if that your breaſt be penetrable to ought thats good.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.p: O no more!

Why ſhould you ring and twiſt that heart that is already broke, I love Euſames and though orepour'd a while, I have not ſignifi'd the force of paſsion as I was wont, yet be ſhall ſoon apprehend a ſudden thaw in that affection which he preſumed was totally anothers.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Noble maid.

Pardon the harſh conjecture that I made, ile uſe no more for fear my fond conceit fall into relapſe, I leave you, and with ſuch a bleſsing as dying Fathers give their only ſons, or ſaints to their penetant votaries.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Worthy Euſames, unto whom I owe,
All that my utmoſt bounty can beſtow!
I will be plain and real in my Love
Which may thy anger yet thy pardon move:
In holy writ, many did chooſe by art
Aſarafice, but nothing like a broken heart.

div.head: Scen fifth.
div.stage: Enter Avaritius with a Letter Lucibella Clara.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: GOne to England.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis very true ſir.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: Her letter declares that diſcontent cauſed her ſudden departure, I hope neither of you were unkind to her.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I hope ſhe ſpeaks of no ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Rightly ſhe cannot.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: I'm ſomthing troubled: but muſt wave it, this is a day appointed for other conſiderations: a happy day for your Daughters, that muſt make your fortunes: my great care has wrought it, and yours muſt be as great to entertain it: they are gentlemen at all points, that when you are married will love, embrace and chain themſelves to your obſervance: nay a great part of their Eſtates too are tyed in a joynture which makes up the harmony, you are contented girls are you not?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: A Husbands welcome, and as an humble wife Ile entertain him (but not the Him you mean) the gentleman I have well obſerved, and he may pleaſe too: It is your pleaſure I ſhould make him mine, and it has been ſtill my duty to obſerve you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I ſir as obediently ſubmit to your pleaſure in embracing Cornelio.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: Good girls, come lets go in then: I love your modeſties to marrow I hope you'l look more womenly.

div.head: Scen. Sixth.

body.p:
Pardon me that I am a little retir'd, the cauſe ſhall be made evident to your honour on the morrow being my Cozens wedding day: I have inform'd my Uncle by letter that I am gone towards England, if he acquaint you therewith, pray contradict it not, not yet fear but at his houſe to morrow I will
meet your embraces, I am and will be more

sp.p: Well 'tis honeſtly done, but piſh Ermenia can't be falſe: ſo much beauty cannot harbour a double heart, I ſee it is not wealth nor riches can purchaſe a fair ſoul, nor had my preſents of gold ere gain'd a ſmile, had not the influence of my Agents eloquence work'd it. O happy man am I that ſhall poſſeſs that matchleſs beauty Venice can boaſt off, that honeſt heavenly heart that can't withdraw a while but muſt acquaint her love and Lord. VVell Cozen thou that haſt been the Authour of my endleſs blis expect a high reward.

See here he is, welcome my noble friend, claim the performance of that high promiſed reward I gave the, upon condition thou couldeſt any way win Ermenia to marry me, ſee here her hand to confirm this ſame. ſhews the letter.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: I hope by this my Lord you are aſſur'd ſhe was not courted ſlightly.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: No thou haſt been diligent and work's effectually, my hand and ſeal to the Deputy of my Exchequer for five hundred Crowns ſhall be thy recompence. within there Pego.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Ink and paper.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: 'Tis at hand my Lord.
sp.stage: A Table ſet forth with ſtandiſh and paper.

div.stage: Gon. writes a note and gives it to Cozen.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Take that and with a promiſe upon my honour to advance the upon any requeſt.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Your Honours bountiful, and for my part I muſt make an humble acknowledgment, ſuch is my obligation to the merit that I ſhould think my beſt of labours crown'd in that Act could ſerve you.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Thou art honeſt and excellent, I ſhall ſee you to morrow queſtionleſs at the Nuptials.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: 'Tis very likely.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Till then farewel.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Good day to your Lordſhip.
sp.l: Now Plothrift if thou thriv'ſt as well as I,
'Tis a compleated peice of Roguery.

div.head: Scen ſeventh.

sp.p: UNto the Man impriſoned, black and obſcure is the clear beauty of the brighteſt day: through Iron grates he only ſees the light and thereby does encreaſe his miſery. Thoſe whom he doth perceive in joy to paſs, augment his wretchedneſs by making him to think that thus I lately was my ſelf. But may I dye abhor'd by mankind if I repine at all. Arm ye gods my love with conſtancy of mind that ſhe may never forget the love of her Euſames. O Ermenia! the exquiſiteſt tortures that by invention ere were made, for the I would think ſports and undergoe.
sp.l: Mayeſt thou live happily and free from care
And all my miſeries of no momentare.

div.stage: Enter Jaylor and Ermenia in mans habit.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: There he is Sir.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.p: Ther's for thy kindneſs Jaylor.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Thank you ſir.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: How do you ſir.

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Not ſo well as I could wiſh you.

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.p: As well as I could wiſh my ſelf and that's ſufficient, you are miſtaken ſir in me, I am no baſe metal to be chang'd at every puff of wind: impriſonment is the leaſt of terrors to daunt a true couragious heart.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Nay be not ſo haſty: I kindly come to viſit you.

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.p: I kindly thank you then.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: So ſir are you ſorry yet for your late deſperate rudeneſs. ſpeaking to Euſames

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.p: Sorry! no ile nere be ſorry had I a term of life and liberty could laſt for ever, and you could give it me, yes and would, for all or more i'de nere be reconcil'd to baſe Gonzetto's, as ignoble in heart, as made noble by thy Titles.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Jaylor.
Double fetter him.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: You are too cruel ſir.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: You ſpeak in vain ſir.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: 'Tis againſt the Law: he is no Fellon.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: It ſhall be done.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: It ſhall?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: It ſhall. you are too bold.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: No more then I can juſtifie. Jaylor forbear: look there high ſwelling Lord.
Throwes him Euſames his pardon purchaſed from the Duke.

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.p: My pardon purchas'd by a ſtranger: 'tis very ſtrange!

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: 'Tis very true.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Well Jaylor you may releaſe him.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: O thank your honour for nothing.

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.p: Sir for this your chriſtian courtiſie with many thanks my beſt of ſervices are indebted to your kindneſs, and all too little to make the leaſt part of requital, yet withall let me intreat one addition of your love: in telling me how or which way you heard of my impriſonment, and upon what grounds you grew ſo kind to procure my pardon.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: I heard of your impriſonment by the relation of a friend of yours named Florentio to a friend of mine, one Mr. Plotthrift by whoſe perſwaſion and my own pitty of your ſufferings, I obtained this grant from the Duke for your liberty, more I have to tell you, lets out of this Goal and you ſhall know all.

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.l: Thus heaven has ſtill a friend in ſtore for thoſe
That have but honeſt hearts though fiery foes.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: NOw Gentlemen judge you whether I have not been very ſerviceable.

sp.speaker: Aquin.
sp.p: In that nature that really I think half my Eſtate a morgage to you.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Indeed I did not doubt your prevaling at the long run, but in ſo ſhort a time that your expedition deſerves a double reward.

sp.speaker: Aquin.
sp.p: My brother and I ere long ſhall ſtudy to requite you, but in the interim pray accept of a few crowns in this bag. gives a bag.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Well Gentlemen I thank you, and if the like or any other ſervice lyes in me to obliege you, you may command it, for the preſent ile take my leave.

sp.speaker: Aquin.
sp.p: Are you in haſte pray? if your occaſions will permit, wee intreat your good company to a glaſs of excellent wine at a friends houſe of mine at the other end of the town.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: All other concerns in me are laid aſide to ſerve you.

sp.speaker: Aquin.
sp.p: Come then we'l call on my Father Avaritius and thither preſently.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: withall my heart.

sp.speaker: Plot
sp.l: So my deſign is laid: but 'tis the end aſide
Muſt crown the work: ſo fortune be my friend.

div.head: Scen firſt.
div.stage: Enter Cozen, Florentio and Euſames diſguiſed with vizards.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: I wonder they come not.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: 'Tis very late.

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.p: Are we ſet right?

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Exactly in the place appointed,

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Huſh I hear a trampling.

div.stage: Enter Plotthrift with a bag and Avaritius.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: Heaven ſend us ſafe home, they did ill to leave us and croſs the fields ſo late.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Come ſir fear not what ſmall defence my ſword and ſervice may be to you ſhall not be wanting.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: Your bag of money there, may cauſe ſome danger: and we have robbing ſpirits walk the ſtreets at this time of night.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: You are very timerous Sir.
sp.stage: They walk off the ſtage and on agen, and they ſeize on them.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Deliver all your money, or you are dead men.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: O Murder, murder, murder!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Nay we'l ſtop your mouthing.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Hellhounds what Devil has ſtir'd you to this madneſs.

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.p: Nay we are not ſo mad to contend but deliver.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Villains redeliver my money or take my life and all, or ile have yours. draws and fights with two.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: Nay pray Gentlemen ſpare my life and take all I have.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: No ſir firſt weel ſtop your mouth. gags him.

div.stage: Plotthrift has routed two and comes and routs the third.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Now villain for you.
sp.stage: They fight a great while and at laſt Coz. runs

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Come Sir take courage I have ſav'd your life though to my loſs of a hundred crowns.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: Sir I thank you and if a thouſand can make you amends you ſhall have them.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: No Sir ile only deſire your hand being a Juſtice of the peace, to a ſmall paper which will benefit a friend of mine in a high manner.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: That I would moſt thankfully were I but at home.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Come Sir ile ſee you ſafe at home ile warrant you.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: I thank you good ſir, heaven keep of a ſecond brunt.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Nere fear it ſir.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: Will they not meet us agen now.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: O 'tis not imaginable, they are all deſperately wounded and they'l hold it the ſafer way to cure thoſe then to come and get more.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: You have a luccky hand.

div.head: Scen. ſceond.
div.stage: Enter Lucibella, Clara and Ermenia in mans habit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: COzen I much commend you, and much more love you now then ever I did.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Your joyes will now increaſe, never fear it. But breach of contracts is a ſecond hell.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
What though his fortunes are at preſent low, when
he injoyes content and happineſs in you, you'l quickly ſee his virtues ſoon will raiſe him, I ſhall wiſh you much joy in him.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And ſo ſhall I.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: I thank you both, and the like I ſhall wiſh you in your elections.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why I, wee never ſtood wavering, but as ſoon as we lov'd a little ſtruck up a blind bargain preſently.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Wee found they were wits and they'l never leave working till they get wealth enough ile warrnt you.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: But how will you get your portions of your father if you marry againſt his will.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: O we never fear that the wheels of their Noddles are working for that deſign.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: You ſhall ſee we'l be married to morrow morn, my Father well pleaſed by noon, we ſporting in bed at night, and as loath to riſe early next morn, as any two couple in Chriſtendome.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Well ile pluck up a good ſpirit too, make a third couple, and ſee if I can be ſerv'd the ſame ſauce.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Gramercy Girl.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Huſh my father knocks.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Up to my chamber.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: I'm gone.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: O girls had it not been for this courteous Gentleman I had been kil'd.

sp.speaker: Luc. and Cla.
sp.p: Kill'd.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: I, kill'd we were ſet upon by Rogues, Villains, Thieves but this Gentleman I thank him preſerv'd me though to his loſs of an hundred Crowns. Here Luci take my key of my desk, there lies a bag of two hundred or thereabouts fetch it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I run ſir.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: Clara call my man bid him bring ink and paper.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I ſhall ſir.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: Pray ſir ſit down and aſſure your ſelf whatſoever lies in poor Avaritius his power to obleige you, you may freely command, for this never to be forgotten courtiſie.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Pray ſir impute this no ſuch obligation, I was bound in nature to defend you.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: O Complement no more, can you obleige me more then ſave my life from murdering Rebels? no 'tis impoſsible. Then life nothing more dear.

div.stage: Enter Lucibella with a bag of money, Clara. Priſcilla and ſervant with a Table, ſtandiſh and paper.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: Here accept of this in part of future recompence.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: You are liberall ſir.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: Now ſir if you'l pleaſe to produce your paper ile ſet my hand produces a large paper.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Pleaſe you ile read it to you firſt ſir.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: No that will be too tedious, only tell me in two or or three words what it means.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Why a friend of mine lately taxed with a ſcurvy buſineſs and ſuſpitiouſly impriſon'd, this is a narrative of his birth and education, to which if you will be pleas'd to ſet your hand, as knowing him it may be a means to procure his Liberty.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: That I will willingly, lets ſee the pen. to his man.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Pray ſir your hand for a witneſs. to his man.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: What iſt ſir.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: Sirrah don't diſpute but write your hand.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I ſhall ſir. writes.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: And yours Madam. to Priſcilla.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Yes ſir. ſhe writes.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: Sir for to night I bid you farewell. 'Tis very late and I am very ſleepy.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Be ſure be ready. Is Ermenia above.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Within this hour Ile call.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Wee'l be ready.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Farewell my Dear.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Adeiu Love till anon.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Farewell Brother.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Now fortune ile adore thee, thou haſt been my Friend indeed. Thou haſt ſign'd me a deed that renders me a noble eſtate, fair Lucibella with thirty thouſand Crowns is mine, the like has Cozen with his Clara, my ſtolen hundred Crowns are doubled too, well ile to my theiving comrogues and then go find out a Prieſt,
sp.l: Proſpitious Heavens by this plots ſucceſs.
Plothrift is rais'd to an endleſs happineſs.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: EXcellent.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.p: Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: How ſavoury the old man ſmelt when we went about to faggot him.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: How like an Owl in an Ive-buſh the Rogue look'd when wee tyed him neck and heels.

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.p: And made ugly faces when we gag'd him.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: O he prayes for his deliverance.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Plot thrift ile warrant you will be his boſome friend, and he has cunning enough to ſqueez him.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: His hundred crowns ile warrant you are doubled.

sp.speaker: Coz.
