sp.p: They are made thouſands by this time I hope or he miſſes of his aim.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: See here he is.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Ha ha ha! Hellhounds what Devil rais'd you to this madneſs? ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: How fares the old man?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: O orejoyed that he's delivered: Gentlemen you are notable rogues and ſhall be my boſome friends as I am his, ſee here a ſlender reward that he has given me.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: How Lucibela with thirty thouſand crowns.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: I think 'tis thirty, I'me ſure twa's writ at length becauſe I wou'd not be miſtaken, look agen.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: The like to me with Clara, O happineſs beyond expreſsion! let me hug thee for thy cunning!

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: I think I have plotted fairely, now nothing is wanting but a preiſt, the Girls are ready at a call.

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.p: Is my Ermenia with them.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Yes!

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.p: Then Sir to you I owe my life: you have loaded me with ſo many ſeveral obligations that I am ready to ſink under their wait, and could my wiſhes but convert themſelves into effects it ſhould be my ambition to ſignifie my ſelf an object worthy of your favours, till then I am your everlaſting debtor.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: You are bountiful in expreſsion, I am more then paid in your favourable acceptance. But come lets go 'tis high time of day.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I can direct you to a prieſt.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: You will obleige us, lead the way you muſt be Father to us all.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Withall my heart.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sure ſome ill fortune has betided them or croſs'd their deſigns.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Ha, ha, fearful Lucibella? fie for ſhame!

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.p: Better be fearful then fool hardy.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Priſ. watch at the window, beſure you do not nod, but give us true warning.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Do ſo Priſcilla.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: I ſhall be careful.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Come wenches what are you for ſinging or dancing.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis the maddeſt wench, fear nothing, ſure thy love is not real, elſe it cou'd not be ſo void of fear.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Well I am reſolv'd to ſing a ſong, we are all alone, and 'tis one of my own compoſure.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Prithee forbear.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Troth but I will, ide have you do the ſame and ſo take leave of ſinging clear, 'twill not be long I hope ere we looſe our voices.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How wildely ſhe talks?

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.p: Come Cozen, begin.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: A comely youth I once beheld
A bathing in a river
Where ſtrait my paſsions rebell'd
And ſcorh't my heart and liver.
Such might Narciſſus beauties be,
But ſcarſe ſo clear ſo white as he,
I veiv'd each part, and ſo
Saw ſomthing down below.
Which made my mind and heart a ramblinggo
High! ho.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: I'm glad ye are ſo merry Ladies.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I'm ſorry your ſo nere Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Come 'tis not time now to chat each minuits worth an hour, come away away.

div.head: Scen fifth.
div.stage: Enter Avaritius, Cook, Butler, and Chamber-maid.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: MY Maſters pray be wary and ſerviceable, Cook ſee all your ſauces be ſharp and poynant in the pallat, that they may commend you: look to the roaſt and boyld meat handſomly, and what new kickſhaws and other de-delicate things you made. Is the Muſick come?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Yes ſit they are at breakfaſt.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: There will be dancing too, you muſt ſee this room clean: Butler let your door be opoen to all good fellows, but have an eye to the Plate for their be Furies. Peg you are for the linnen, ſort it and ſeek it ready for the Table, and ſee the Bride beds made, and ſee the cords be not cut aſſunder by the Gallants too, there be ſuch knacks abroad, ſo go in all to your ſeverall duties.
I now begin to remember I ſign'd a certain writing to Mr. Plotthrift laſt night, but what it was I know not. Zachary.
Zachary what writing was it Mr. Plotthrift deſired me to ſet my hand too: did you ſee it?

sp.speaker: Zac.
sp.p: No ſir?

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: No ſir, and why no ſir?

sp.speaker: Zac.
sp.p: Becauſe he told you what it was and you was ſatisfied and bid me ſet my hand.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: What did he tell me it was.

sp.speaker: Zac.
sp.p: A Narrative of a Gentlemans condition in priſon.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: What, I ſet my hand to warrant him before me.

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: Some ſuch thing ſir.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: Very likely: go in.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: My noble Lord moſt hearty welcome: good morrow noble Bridegroomes.

sp.speaker: Aquin. and Cor.
sp.p: Thank you father, are your Daughters ready? 'tis high time for to ſend for the Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: Not yet I think: have a little patience and they'l come down preſently ile warrant you, but my Lord you have not heard of my Neeces departure.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Yes ſir indeed to my great grief, I ſorrow much for her abſence; but now perforce muſt ſtudy to forget I ever ſaw her,

sp.speaker: Ava,
sp.p: She went away abruptly, without taking her leave I know no reaſon for't, but come my Lord and Sons that quickly muſt be will you walk into a glaſs of wine.

sp.speaker: Aquin and Cor.
sp.p: We attend you.

div.head: Scen ſixth.
div.stage: Enter Plotthrift, Lucibella, Clara, Euſames Ermenia. in mans habit Florentio and Preiſt.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: HO! houſe! who's within!

sp.speaker: Zac.
sp.p: Who would you ſpeak with?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Wher's your Maſter within?

sp.speaker: Zac.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Id'e deſire to ſpeak a word with him.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: Here he is ſir.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Sir your ſervant I come to beg a boon of you.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: My life! no ſooner ask'd but granted, name it.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: I take you at your word Sir, thank you, be pleaſed to give me and my friend joy with your daughters.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: Why are you married?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: This grave Gentleman will ſatisfie you if you doubt it.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: Abus'd cheated, gull'd, abus'd my daughters loſt and undone.

sp.speaker: Aquin.
sp.p: How your daughters loſt and undone.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: I married to Vagabonds, Sychophants, and I know not whom!

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Your ſervant Seniors, we have the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Your ſervant Seniors, we have the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.p: Your ſervant my Lord I have the Lady.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: 'sdeath! — in a maze. Am I awake, I vow to ſend ſome to their eternal reſt. And make 'em ſleep for ever? — draws.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Pray ſir be well adviz'd, conſider firſt what plea you have to commit this outrage, your honour Sir can't bear you out in't.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: Sir what is done was by Avaritius free conſent, ſo that if you find your ſelves abus'd in any particular: 'twas cheifly done by him.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: By me? 'tis falſe, my Lord diſcredit him, meer cheats and impoſters!

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Come ſir to ſatisfie you and all theſe Gentlemen whoſe miſled opinions thought us meerly the actors and contrivers in this plot, ſee here. produces the writings.
Theſe with your own hand ſign'd and ſeal'd in the preſence of Lucibella, Clara and Priſ. beſides Zacharias, Tobit your clark, what ſay ye all iſt not true?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis undeniable.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Moſt true an't ſhall like you ſir.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: I muſt confirm it too.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: O patience!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Troth this is very well, 'tis true I alwaies thought ſhe had too much wit for me.

sp.speaker: Aquin.
sp.p: Well Heavens be thanked we bear not all the baffle on our own backs, well —

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: I am only ſorry you ſpent ſo much cull'd courtſhip to ſo little purpoſe

sp.speaker: Aquin.
sp.p: I muſt bear it.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: I could rage too, but 'twill be to full as little effect, come Juſtice you ought to bear it beſt of all, Pox on't, this 'tis when old men muſt frolick and be drunk at the Tavern, cou'd you have kept your ſelf ſober on your daughters wedding even, all had been well then, but now let things go how they will, Gentlemen I wiſh you as much joy with your Ladies as I expected.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We thank ye, Plot. Come father in Law lets hear as much from you. We'l maintain your daughters according to their birth and fortunes.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.p: That we will.

sp.speaker: Euſ.
sp.p: And I your Neece according to my abillity, and what is wanting in that, ile make up with love and good husbandry.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: VVhy this is ſome comfort, Gentlemen pardon me, I muſt be contented: well I forgive and give you my daughters freely, and with them their portions of thirty thouſand crowns a peice, you ſir my Neece with twenty, and ſo my bleſsing with you all.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Thank you dear Father, and pardon us that we have choos'd thoſe whom we lov'd and hope to live with comfort.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.p: I hope ſo too.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: My Lord I beg your excuſe to Gonzetto. had I not been contracted ere I knew your Honor you had been the only man ſhould have enjoyed me, and my laſt letter to you was only to obleige you to be here, to ſee how I am beſtowed in which you have honored me and I humbly thank you.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Ermenia I am not ſo angry, but I can tell you that my love and eſteem of you is ſtill as great as ever, though I am debarr'd that happineſs of enjoying you: yet I wiſh you a life ſo circled in with joy, that you may never breath a ſigh, and when you ſhall grow weary of the earth become Joves dotage and be Queen of heaven, come Gentlemen be not ſo uncharitable but give joy. to Aquin and Cor.

sp.speaker: Aquin. and Coz.
sp.p: No ſir we wiſh all joy and happineſs.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: VVe thank you, come lets have a dance or two and ſo to dinner.

sp.speaker: Coz. and Euſ.
sp.p: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Ava.
sp.l: Well now,
Lets into dinner, but firſt take my vogue,
No Italian knave like to an Engliſh Rogue.

div.head: The Epilogue.
div.stage: Spoken by a Meſſenger of State and Plot-thrift.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: PLot-thrift Impoſter! Thou muſt forthwith come
Before the Councel board: They have past a doom,
For thy Impriſonment: Upon Information
Thou art a Rogue and Cozens the whole Nation.
Only theſe Ladies ſmiles can ſet thee free
But if they frown you muſt too Goal with me,

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.l: And hang my ſelf for want of Liberty
How like you this Coz. As I am a ſinner,
An ill diſh of News at a Wedding Dinner!
Ladies, O dear Ladies, what ſhall I ſay
Pox take that Engliſh Rogue that writ the Play!
Won't you be kind to ſmile and clap me too?
Should y'e ask me I'de do as much for you.
Be not cloſe fiſted: Conſider that it may
Be your own caſe to want another day:
You may command me then and thereupon
Ile faithfully repay you three for one.
Joyn all your forces now and ſet me free,
One ſcore of Claps and I'm at liberty. (Clap)
Now Gentlemen I hope you'r ſatisfied
On the ſame Covenants to clap my Bride. (Clap agen)
